reviews.review_msg: Not a considerate person. Does not care about his students. Conceited for no reason.
Made accounting interesting, but he does go off topic a lot in lectures. He tells u what's going to be on the exam which is nice, but doesn't allow a cheat sheet during exams

Robin spends too much class time promoting Big 4 careers. The final exam was very challenging, with a class average of 45%.

That said, his lectures are engaging and students enjoy his teaching style. There is always a lineup to talk to him after class, and he consistently stays late to make sure every student's questions are answered.
He is making one of the hardest courses very engaging. Super responsive and kind. The best part that he is a nice person, which is a rare thing at SFU. Take Robin if you can!

Robin expects his students to have same level of knowledge as he does, and this is reflected in his exams.
Final had a class average of 45%
The tests are tough, but the worst part-he gives way less time than what's required. He himself stated that only 5% students in the whole class would be able to complete the exam. Knowledge is not being tested.

By far, the best prof that I've taken. He is very organized and knows exactly what he's doing. Encourages questions and gives very practical answers. Makes the expectations around exams extremely clear. He genuinely cares about his students' success, not just at school but in life outside of school as well!

Robin is funny, so lectures are engaging, but the weekly political tangents get tedious. Homework is easier than the exam, which he tells you the questions forâ€”but they're tricky, so do lots of textbook practice. Reading the textbook isn't very helpful, and the slides are quite simple, so it is hard to catch-up if you miss a lecture.

I take his class after my 9-5 and despite the exhaustion, I attend lecture with excitement. Sure he can be very expressive, but that's the very thing keeping everyone engaged. 
I hope he stays at SFU for as long as possible.

Robin's lectures are very engaging (although he does enjoy talking about politics...)-- his in-class practice examples are well-thought out, and it's clear that he knows what he is doing. Also, a genuinely nice guy. Would recommend!

Very test heavy; to do well, do as many practice questions as you can, and be prepared for tricky details on tests!
Fun. Enjoyable. Actually enjoyed his class and participate all class although participation not mandatory. Strongly recommend.

Exams are pretty tough and very time-constrained with low averages, but he will tell you what type of questions will be on the exams. In order to do well stay on top of practice Q's, Wiley HW, and pre-readings. Overall 10/10 guy. Hilarious and good lecturer.

Worth delaying your graduation to take his lectures. Took 320, 321 and 420 with him. You will gain a much deeper understanding of accounting just by attending his lectures. Questions are encouraged and he answers them flawlessly. The course material is brutal but he somehow makes it interesting. Amazing lecturer and a wonderful human being

Robin is one of the best profs out there, defo take a class with him if you can. Grade is mostly based on exams, which are very time-constrained with low averages. To practice, do the end of chapter questions based on the stuff he tells you to study (very transparent with exams). Keep doing it over and over until you can do it quickly & correctly!

Robin makes learning accounting fun and seem easier than other profs make it out to be. He is funny, genuinely cares about his students learning, and gives out good career advice. He doesn't answer his emails quickly, but I don't blame him b/c he spends so much time  in office hours to make sure everyone's questions are heard and solved. 10/10 guy

Robin is a terrific prof! He is super entertaining and covers all material in a clear manner. Exams are definitely tough and time-constrained, so lots of practice is required. Make sure to do and understand all the homework and self-study problems. He gives you the exact format of the exam, so focus only on what he mentions. Textbook reading helps!
Best accounting prof. He genuinely cares about the success of his students and is passionate about what he teaches.

Robin is humorous and provides good advice and tips to aspiring CPAs within his lectures. He was considerate to students by recording lectures and omitting part of the final that had a tech error. Weekly homework assignments and quizzes were time consuming, but good practice. Exam questions are the same as the homework and examples from class.
